assignments.name: MANDATORY ASSIGNMENT: Recollection of Death and Loss Paper
assignments.description:
Recollection of Death and Loss Paper

Here's what I am asking you to do:

Write a chronological narrative of your deaths and losses. Start with your first experience of death or loss and move chronologically through your life, writing about 5 or 6 of your most significant experiences of death and loss. (If you can't think of that many losses in your life, even minor ones, that is okay—write about all the ones you can think of.) Reflect on the event, your emotions and actions, and the actions of others. Deaths may include family, friends, neighbors, pets....  Losses or separations may include divorce (of parents or yourself), moving, or the end of a relationship with a friend or boyfriend/girlfriend. Recapture the feelings associated with that experience. It is helpful to create in your mind a picture of the occasion. 

If you are worried about revisiting these losses alone, please talk to Dr. Marla Nedelcu or your section instructor. We will work with you. You could also ask someone you love to just sit somewhere in the room with you, doing their own thing, but giving silent support. Remember the chaplains' and counselors' numbers and hotlines that are listed under "Modules"/"Mental Health Resources."

Here are some other things you can do if memories become difficult:

1. Pray for God's comforting Presence to be with you.

2. Take a break and go outside

3. Take a short walk. 

4. Breathe deeply and use your senses to look around the room—what do you see and smell? What do your hands feel? Those things will bring you back to the present.

5. Call a friend and talk. 

6. Go hug your dog or cat. 

7. Have a tasty drink, a special blanket, or a favorite fragrant candle nearby.

8. Listen to uplifting music.

9. Think ahead. What else might give you healthy comfort?

Here's why I am asking you to do it:

If you aren't able to handle your own grief healthily, you will not be able to give long-term compassionate care to your patients. You will burn out or become hardened. This project aims to further explore your personal attitudes toward death and take you back to past experiences with death and loss. Ignored and unexpressed grief can stunt our emotional growth, dull our ability to feel good emotions, and make forming close, healthy relationships difficult. Not only is awareness and processing of your grief healthy for you, but it will also help you be able to connect to your patients and their families in ways that are healing. Your privacy will be respected. Your section instructor (and possibly Prof. Patterson and/or Dr. Nedelcu) are the only persons who will read your recollections. 

Here's how to do it:

Keep this list close to you as you write your stories. Please carefully include the answers to each of these questions in your narrative. Start with your earliest death/loss experience and include the following information.

  • How old were you?
  • What/who died or was lost to you?
  • How did you feel?
  • How did you react?
  • Who else was there?
  • How did they act and seem to feel?
  • Were you there when the person died or was lost to you? If so, share your experience.
  • Did you attend the funeral? If so, share your experience (if the loss was a death).
  • What was the long-term effect of the person's death/loss on you and your family?
      
In your concluding paragraph include:
  • How your reactions to death/loss have changed from your first experience to the most recent.
  • Do you believe you have a healthy reaction to death or loss? Why/why not?
  • This is worth 4 points. Please don't forget this last paragraph.

Format:

  • Essay style. Write in paragraphs, not bulleted lists.
  • APA-style cover page
  • APA format (7th edition)
    • Double-spaced with original default margins
    • Good grammar and spelling
    • No minimum or maximum page limit as different people will have different life experiences. However, minimal exploration will receive minimal points (because it will do you minimal good).

assignments.name: What Adventists Believe About Death: Pastor Mark Finley Interview
assignments.description:
Dear Students,

How can hold your own beliefs while respecting the beliefs of your patient?  This is an important question that is also addressed in the Diversity Project.  In the video below, Pastor Mark Finley will address what Seventh-day Adventists believe the Bible says about what happens when people die.

Here's what I am asking you to do:

  • Watch the video interview and answer the 4 questions which you will find at the end of these directions.

Here's why I am asking you to do it:

1. I thought you might be curious as to how this belief is different from what you might have heard. 

2. You are in an Adventist university, and there's a good chance you will be hired to work in the AdventHealth system, so it makes sense for you to know what Seventh-day Adventists believe on this. It will help you respond in a way that is helpful, if you are a nurse, for example, and you are taking care of a Seventh-day Adventist mother who just lost a baby.  It would not be comforting to her for you to say, "Don't be sad.  Your baby is a little angel watching over you in heaven now," as she wouldn't believe that. 

3. I wanted to share some of my personal beliefs with you because they have been a blessing to me. You will be graded on clearly understanding what Pastor Finley is presenting. You will not be graded for thinking differently than Pastor Finley or I believe. If the Bible teaches that only God is immortal and the human soul is mortal, and I believe it does, then there are some important implications for our understanding of many things.  Take hell, for instance.  If the human soul is mortal, then why would God assign people to an eternally burning hell?  When they have only lived a sinful life for 70-80 years, why would he keep torturing them forever? Why would a loving God continue to keep them alive, constantly recreating their nerve endings so they could feel pain?  To me, that belief is an injustice to who God is.  And who we think God is will have an impact on our relationship with Him.  I am interested in hearing what you think! 

When the Bible talks about the eternal aspect of hell, is it talking about people burning forever?  Or that the effect is eternal?  To say it another way:  If I hold a paper to a flame, will the paper burn forever?  OR is it burned up forever? I believe the Bible teaches the latter. 

I believe that part of being a loving God IS to be a just God.  And that when Jesus comes the second time, He will come, not as a baby, but as a conquering King.  And He will say to the wicked, who will be raised at that time, "You may not torture and rape; no more incest, no more murder, no more war.  No more sexual trafficking, racial injustice, domestic violence, or even gossiping and selfishness.  You may not treat my children like this anymore.  You have chosen the way of death, and you may have what you have chosen."  And then He will clean the world by fire, and the result will be eternal since Satan, sin, and sinful people will be no more. There will not be a place in the universe where God is constantly burning people.  He will create a new earth - without sin and pain. If you would like to discuss this further and look at Bible texts on this, please contact me.

Here's how to do it:

  • Watch the video with Mark Finley all the way through, taking notes.
  • Answer the 4 questions you will find below.
  • Each answer should:
    • Be numbered
    • Include the questions in bold type
    • Show thought and proofreading
    • Be at least 100 words
    • Include the word count in parentheses at the end.  Like this: (WC 103).

Question 1:  Please explain in simple terms what Pastor Mark Finley and Seventh-day Adventists believe the Bible says about death.

Question 2. Of the topics covered in this lecture, which was most interesting to you and why?

Question 3:  Is this belief comforting or discomforting to you?  Why?

Question 4:  Pastor Finley outlined what Adventists believe the Bible says about the state of the dead.  Before watching the video, what was your belief about what happens when people die?  Has it changed since watching the interview? If so, why?  If unsure, why?  If not, why?

assignments.name: Reading & Response: Your Choice: "Compassionomics" or "Hard Choices"
assignments.description:
Dear Students, 

I thought you would appreciate this tweet a student sent:  “I saw the attached tweet & it made me think of this class, specifically the discussions surrounding intentional and careful word choice.”  (See below.)

This week you have a choice for your Required Reading.  

Here's what I am asking you to do:

Choose between finishing Hard Choices by Frank Dunn, Chapters 4-5 (pp. 29-75) or the introductory chapter to the book Compassionomics.  This will be a HARD CHOICE!

Here's why I am asking you to do it:

I absolutely could not choose between these two reading assignments as they are both important for you in caring for your patients.

Chapter Four of Hard Choices gives practical help for decision-making towards end-of-life, e.g., when and if to hospitalize, use a ventilator, do dialysis, etc.  Chapter Five, "The Journey to Letting Be" gently and thoughtfully helps the loving family members decide when it is time to let go and let be.

The Introduction and Chapter 1 of Compassionomics

Compassion is one of the competencies that candidates for employment at AdventHealth are assessed for when they interview. I know that's not the only reason you are interested in being a compassionate caregiver, but I thought you would be interested in seeing the immediate relevance. 

I’m excited to share with you part of a book that has the potential to change how people experience healthcare. It’s called Compassionomics: The Revolutionary Scientific Evidence That Caring Makes a Difference. This is a book that was widely read by the executives at AdventHealth - and, in fact, was recommended to me by one of them. I have uploaded the end of the introduction and part of the first chapter for you to read. I believe it will put you ahead in your field to know about this book and have read some of it. You also might want to use it in reports for other classes.  I highly recommend reading the rest of this book - since you are a class that is going to make a difference in this area! There is a copy in the library.

Here's how to do it:

1. Make your choice about what to read.

2. If Hard Choices: Read chapters 4-5. Write 3-4 sentences about what was the most meaningful or interesting to you in each chapter. There are 5 points for each. Here is the link if you need it again. Hard Choices by Hank Dunn: Hard Choices for Loving People: CPR, Artificial Feeding, Comfort Care, and the Patient with a Life-Threatening Illness.

3. If Compassionomics: Read the Introduction portion and Chapter 1. Write 3-4 sentences about what was most meaningful or interesting to in both the Introduction and Chapter 1. There are 5 points for each.  

4. Reference the page number(s) of the concept(s) you found most helpful. 

5. Reference them like this: (p. 39).   (This is not APA-style in-text referencing but will be simpler for this assignment.)

assignments.name: Interview with Dr. Park
assignments.description:
Dear Students,

What I want you to do:

  1. Read the following information about Ambiguous Grief.
  2. Watch the video below.
  3. Answer the Questions.

1. Healthy Grief. Dr. Park described healthy grief as grief that progresses - or doesn't get stuck.  She then used the metaphor of a "box" that holds difficult things that happen to us. If you drew your box, what would it look like? Interpret your picture.  (OR you may describe your box in words and interpret your description.)

2. Ambiguous Loss.  Pauline Voss, the foremost expert on "Ambiguous Loss," defines it this way, "Ambiguous loss differs from ordinary loss in that there is no verification of death or no certainty that the person will come back or return to the way they used to be."  She describes two kinds of ambiguous loss:

Type One is when there is physical absence with psychological presence. This is when a loved one is physically missing or bodily gone. An example of this would be how the family/friends of a soldier would feel if he goes missing in action or when the body of a drowning victim is never found. Other examples are divorce, adoption, how an immigrant feels when they can no longer be physically with their loved ones in the country they left, and so on.  There was a lot of ambiguous grief during COVID!

Type Two is when there is psychological absence with physical presence. This occurs when a loved one is psychologically absent—that is, emotionally or cognitively gone or missing, but still present in the body.  Examples: Alzheimer's, dementia, traumatic brain injuries, or anything that takes away a person's memory and cognition.

If you are interested in Ambiguous Loss and would like to learn more, her book Ambiguous Loss: Learning to Live with Unresolved Grief is an excellent resource!

 

Questions:

1. Dr. Park described healthy grief as grief that progresses - or doesn't get stuck.  She then used the metaphor of a "box" that holds difficult things that happen to us. If you drew your box, what would it look like? Interpret your picture.  (OR you may describe your box in words and interpret your description.)

2.  a) From the material above, how would you define "Ambiguous Loss"?  b) Refer to a story Dr. Park told where the loss is ambiguous.

assignments.name: LECTURE: Death Happens & Discussion Post
assignments.description:
This week, your initial post should be posted by WEDNESDAY, 11:59 pm ET (10 pts.). NO response posts to classmates on this discussion this week, because you will have a response post due for your Diversity Project on Sunday.

Dear Students,

This lecture is presented by Prof. Alicia Patterson and guest lecturer Lynell LaMountain. It addresses the inevitability and causes of death.

Here's what I am asking you to do:

  • Watch the video lecture above, post your answer to the question below on the discussion board (no classmate response posts required this week), and be ready for a quiz. 
    • Here is the question:  "What was the most interesting or meaningful thing you gleaned from Lynell LaMountain?"
  • Always watch lectures to the end as that is how you "attend class."  
  • Note: Please use the Chrome browser to watch Panopto videos.  (Especially with a Mac.) 

Here's why I am asking you to do it:

The question is not if we will die, but when (unless Jesus comes before we die!).  Someone or something teaches you how to do taxes - because it's normal for people to have to do them.  But almost no one gets a class on how to deal with death.   (Lucky you!)    

But really, if something is going to happen at some point, isn't it better to prepare and to be informed?  While it can raise anxiety at first if you've never really thought about it, being informed and prepared can also lower your fear and help you feel calmer and more confident in the face of death.  This lecture addresses the fact that death is inevitable and looks at the most common kinds of death and the reasons behind them.

Here's how to do it: You can decide if you want to write the response to the question or take a video of yourself talking about your response.

If you choose to WRITE your initial post to a lecture:

  • Include the question you are responding to in bold type.
  • Reference the lecture.
  • Show thought and proofreading.
  • Your answer should be at least 100 words. 
  • Include the word count in parentheses at the end.  Like this: (WC 103).

If you choose to RECORD (instead of write) your initial post to a lecture:

  • Answer the question by reading the question out loud before answering.
  • Reference the lecture. 
  • Be insightful and show that you watched the video thoroughly. 
  • Fully and comprehensively answer the question in 2 minutes or more.
  • You must answer the one question indicated in the instructions above, but if you would like to also answer other questions listed in lecture, you may do that as well (to fill up your 2 minutes of recording time).

assignments.name: Diversity Project
assignments.description:
Here's what I'm asking you to do

  • Research a religion, culture, handicap, OR generation that is different from your own.  (You only have to pick ONE of these topics.)  Present information that would impact their EOL (end-of-life) care and write a case study. Do this on your own. This is not a group project. Please click on the 3 dots to the right to see the rubric.  Follow it carefully. 
  • The Presentation should have 7 slides:
    • 1 title slide which includes your name
    • 1 slide with general information about that religion, culture, handicap, or generation
    • 3 slides describing how end-of-life, death, and the afterlife are approached from your patient's perspective
    • 1 slide with your Case Study
    • 1 slide that includes your references
  • Slides should be attractive and have pictures/design that match the content.
  • Post your Presentation by Sunday, Jan 26, at 11:59 pm ET (but you'll want to post it earlier so that you can submit your classmate response in time too).  Your presentation is worth 65 pts.
  • Also post your Response to a classmate's Case Study by Sunday, Jan 26, at 11:59 pm ET. Your response is worth 15 pts.

AN IMPORTANT NOTE ABOUT ACADEMIC INTEGRITY:

The writing on these slides must be your original writing (unless you properly quote and/or cite a reference).  This applies to every assignment for this class.  If you want to quote a source, put quotation marks around what you want to use, and cite the reference.  If you want to use text that came from generative AI, use quotation marks and cite the reference (here is an example: https://apastyle.apa.org/blog/how-to-cite-chatgptLinks to an external site.). If you are borrowing just an idea (but not exact words) from a source, you do not have to use quotation marks, but you must still cite the reference you are using (including with generative AI).  It's important for you to know that papers that are flagged for plagiarism because they use words or ideas from other sources without citing them will receive a score of "0" and further academic disciplinary action may be taken.  The software we use to check each assignment for plagiarism will also identify text that originates from artificial intelligence (if you have not quoted and/or cited it correctly). Please let your section instructor know if you have any questions about this or any other aspect of this project.  

Here's why I am asking you to do it

To broaden your understanding of another person's beliefs outside of your own.  To equip you to show respect to your patient by having an "informed compassion" that allows you to personalize their patient care.  

Here's how to do it

  1. RUBRIC. Click on the three dots to the right and read through your rubric.
  2. RESEARCH. Pick a religion, culture, handicap, or generation from the sign-up list that is different from your own.  There can be two people per category; however, each one will research and present their own project.

    • Personalizing Patient Care is required for this project. It is an excellent, concise resource and is used in the AdventHealth system.   The AdventHealth Press has permitted us to post an e-book version of Personalizing Patient Care to your course in Canvas until all students can return to Campus and access the print book in the library.  This is very generous of them since it is a $40+ book!  See the link below:

      To access Personalizing Patient Care,  double-click here:   https://my.ahu.edu/sites/default/files/PatientCare_Final_low%20res_0.pdf

    • Read everything on your choice of a religion/culture/handicap/generation in the book A Desk Reference to Personalizing Patient Care by Aurora Realin. You must use Realin as your first resource.
    • Use at least two other sources on your specific topic (for example a website put out by that culture or religion) to deepen and broaden your understanding of how to compassionately care for those patients in a clinical setting.  This is a way to have "informed compassion."
    • It will be easier to create a presentation with some topics from the sign-up sheet, and it could be more challenging with others. For example, a presentation on Jewish beliefs of end-of-life, death, and afterlife will be more straightforward to create than a presentation on the end-of-life, death, and afterlife beliefs of the hearing impaired. How can you still make a great presentation out of a more challenging topic? First, try to find whatever research you can on that group's beliefs on end-of-life, death, and afterlife. Second, you may also draw on anecdotal evidence. For example, if you have a friend who is hard-of-hearing, do you know how they might think about these issues? See if you can interview someone about this topic, or find an interview or story online that might touch on some of these topics. Third, feel free to make plausible inferences of how your chosen group might in general feel about this topic. For example, it would seem plausible that a patient who is hard of hearing would feel frustrated by overhearing discussion of end-of-life choices without having someone explain these choices in a way that could be easily understood. Or, with an autistic patient--the uncertainty around death might be even more anxiety-inducing if they thrive on knowing and following a plan. Or, for a patient in a wheelchair because of orthopedic impairment, they may find the afterlife especially meaningful because of a belief that they will be able to finally walk in heaven. With these more challenging topics, whether you rely on research, anecdotal evidence, or personal reflection, please state your source in the presentation. Just put a parentheses after the idea you wrote, identifying where it came from (even if it is your own personal reflection).
  3. PRESENT. Make a short presentation for your classmates (see above). You do not have to do a voice-over or video.  (Your presentation is worth 65 pts.)
  4. MAKE A CASE STUDY. Please imagine a scenario where knowing your patient's end-of-life care, death, and afterlife beliefs and practices will be important to your care for them. Create a case study where someone in your vocation is in that scenario but does at least three (3) things incorrectly.  For example, the healthcare provider makes assumptions and says or does things that could be offensive because they do not personalize their patient's care. Do not include WHY the patient/family reacts negatively.  Just build the scene and leave that for a classmate to figure out by reading your presentation. (Your response is worth 15 pts.)
  5. REFERENCE. Your last slide should reference Personalizing Patient Care and 2 other references in APA style. The library website has APA guidelines and librarians are always willing to help with formatting references. 
  6. UPLOAD a Word document that contains ONLY THE TEXT from your PowerPoint presentation. We will not grade your Project until you upload this Word document as well as the PowerPoint, and you will be deducted points daily for lateness until both are successfully uploaded. 
  7. RESPOND.  A) Choose a classmate's presentation that no one else has chosen yet.  (Make sure it is a different culture/religion/generation/handicap than the one you presented on.)  B.) Read your classmate's presentation and then respond to the case study using the information in their presentation to identify what was done incorrectly.  What religious beliefs or cultural norms made the patient/family react negatively? What might the HCP have done differently?   
  8. CHECK THE RUBRIC. Please click on the 3 dots to the right to see the rubric.  Make sure your project matches the rubric before you turn it in.

Following is an example of a short case study:

SAMPLE CASE STUDY: Sikhism Religion Case Study

An 18-year-old male presented to the emergency department with a laceration near his groin. During intake, making light conversation, the nurse asked him if he followed the Sikh religion. The nurse thought she recognized the special head covering the patient wore. Later, another nurse, a male, came to perform the initial exam. The patient was praying when the nurse came, and the nurse interrupted the patient to say that he was ready to start the exam.  The exam included cleaning the laceration and shaving the affected area, which the nurse did without asking consent from the patient. The nurse told the patient that Dr. Charity Nboko would be in shortly to take a closer look at the wound as it would likely require sutures. The patient politely requested that the male nurse perform the suturing instead of the female doctor. Without consulting with anyone else, the nurse stated that this would be impossible and that the patient should go somewhere else for care.

(Case study adapted from: Carr, F.C., Sorajjakool, S., & Bursey, E.J., eds. [2024]. World religions for healthcare professionals [3rd ed., pp. 123-124]. Routledge.)

SAMPLE RESPONSE: What went wrong?  

Practitioners of the Sikh faith value modesty and privacy. They would feel dishonored by exposing themselves physically to a healthcare provider of the opposite sex. In addition, they are taught to honor God by not cutting their hair. So, if a healthcare professional must cut or shave their patient's hair, they should at least first consult with the patient about this. Finally, prayer is very sacred to a Sikh. Thus if possible it should not be interrupted.

assignments.name: LECTURE: Death Meanings & Discussion Posts
assignments.description:
Dear Students,

I hope you enjoy these interviews that I recorded with hospice chaplain David Labrador.  Please watch both of them. Your discussion post question is given in one of them. Also remember that there will be questions from these videos on this module's quiz.

Blessings,

Dr. Nedelcu

Here's what I am asking you to do

  • Watch both video interviews above, and pay attention to the discussion question that is asked in one of them.  I will not tell you the discussion questions here, but I will list some of the terms that are referenced in that question: closed awareness, suspected awareness, mutual pretense, and open awareness. Please post your answer to this question on the discussion board, and respond to two classmates' posts. Make sure to be ready for a quiz on the whole lecture. 
  • Always watch lectures to the end as that is how you "attend class."  Attendance is counted towards part of your grade.  To be counted present, please watch the whole video.
  • Note: Please use the Chrome browser to access Canvas and watch Panopto videos.  (Especially with a Mac.) 

Here's why I am asking you to do it

  • Death can mean different things to different people.  Differences have been found between the ways doctors and nurses feel about caring for a dying patient, for instance.  And what does time mean to someone who is terminal?  Or space?  How does a patient become aware they are terminal?  How should they be approached with that knowledge?  Those are the kinds of things this lecture addresses.  

All 3 of your posts (your initial post and your 2 response posts) should be posted by Sunday, 11:59 pm ET (initial post = 10 pts. and response posts = 2.5 pts. each).

assignments.name: How to Communicate Honesty and Compassion to the Dying: "Ten Steps" video and "Being Mortal" documentary
assignments.description:
Dear Students,

Here's what I'm asking you to do:

Watch 2 things:  A 5-minute video on how to deliver a terminal prognosis to a patient, and a 54-minute documentary, Being Mortal.  You will then answer some questions from your knowledge of those 2 resources.

Here's why I'm asking you to do it:

The Human Connection of Palliative Care: Ten Steps for What to Say Do is imminently practical and helpful. It is a very effective use of 5 minutes!

Being Mortal is a PBS Frontline documentary (Emmy-nominated) which illustrates the message of the highly-acclaimed book by the same name. Atul Gawande, a professor of surgery at Harvard Medical School, is the author of the book and is featured in the documentary. The documentary "examines the relationships between doctors and patients nearing the end of life, and how the medical profession can better help people navigate mortality. The ultimate goal, after all, is not a good death but a good life — to the very end." (from the documentary description)

Here's how to do it:

  1. Watch this 5-minute video:  The Human Connection of Palliative Care: Ten Steps for What to Say and Do and write out what the 10 Steps are, for this assignment.
  2. Also watch the 54-minute documentary: Being Mortal and answer these 4 questions:
    1. What is something helpful you learned from the story of Atul Gawande's father? OR, How would you have handled the situation with Atul Gawande's father differently?
    2. What is something helpful you learned from the story of Jeff Shields? OR, How would you have handled the situation with Jeff Shields differently?
    3. What is something helpful you learned from the approach that palliative care physician Kathy Selvaggi took when relating to terminal patients? OR, How would you have handled the situation with her patient Norma Babineau differently?
    4. What impact would you want these two videos to have on your (1) personal and (2) professional life?
  3. Italicize your answers so they can be easily distinguished from the questions that you should copy to your assignment.

Let us know if you have any questions or need any support.

Blessings,

Dr. Nedelcu

assignments.name: LECTURE: Nathan's Story & Discussion Posts
assignments.description:
Dear Students,

As Dr. Jay Perez said at the beginning, "We live our lives as stories."  It is often through stories that we learn best - about who we are, who God is, and how to live our lives well. Stories help us decide to do things differently through positive and negative examples.  They inspire and instruct.  Here, I am offering a story that is very dear to our family.  It is not a typical lecture, but I hope you will learn, indirectly, much that will bless you personally and benefit you as you work with your patients.

Here's what I am asking you to do:

  • Watch the video lecture above, and pay attention to the 3 questions that are asked.  Please post your answer to Question #2 on the discussion board, and be ready for a quiz on the whole lecture. Then respond to 2 classmates' posts.
  • Always watch lectures to the end as that is how you "attend class." 

Here's why I am asking you to do it:

How do you trust God when you don't know what the outcome will be? I am hoping this story will not only make you a better healthcare provider but will strengthen your faith in a loving, personal God. It is my prayer that through this story, some of the fear brought forth by the pandemic will be reduced - that even if we don't get the miracle, we will know God is present and God is good.  

If you would like to hear the sermon I preached right before Nathan's incident, click on this link and scroll to the bottom of the page to view the first lecture: Nathan Sermons. (Links to an external site.) There are three other sermons on the page that are also connected to Nathan’s heart event, which you may also view if you’d like.

assignments.description:
A Child's Grief Video 

This is an excellent video on the way children process grief.  The truths it teaches about children and grief are relevant and important. I hope you will watch this video carefully.  The students who do come away with profound realizations and helpful tools.

To get full points your answers need to contain specific things from the video which make it clear you have watched it.

Here is the link:

https://ahu.instructure.com/courses/245/pages/a-childs-grief

assignments.name: Having the Conversation with Someone You Care About
assignments.description:
Dear Students,

 In this assignment you will be putting what you have learned in this class into practice by having an end-of-life conversation with someone in your own family. It is invaluable to hear a loved one's perspective on end-of-life and to know more clearly what they want.  It can save so much misunderstanding and heartache.  Listening to a different perspective on end-of-life than your own also adds to your knowledge base of what your patients might want and gives you practice how to have a hard conversation with them.

This can be a difficult conversation to have.  I would like you to hear from two former students about their experiences:

  1. "At the start of this conversation, I was scared and nervous. I did not want to know. I felt that when end-of-life situations come, I would just cross that bridge when I get there. However, I have completely changed my perspective. I know now that the information we talked about will be less of a burden on me and my family because we will be able to know all that she [her mom] wanted and be able to make her happy until the end. Even though I have high hopes, this situation will not be for a while, it is always good to be prepared."

  2. "I am glad this assignment was incorporated because it made me step out of my box and face the challenges and fears I have when it comes to talking to my loved ones about the process of end-of-life care and what they would desire. I had a difficult time at first, but overall the experience was an eye-opener for me and made me feel stronger and has helped me to talk about these situations, whereas before I would refuse to."

As you prepare for this conversation, you will need to:

1. Download the Starter Kit by clicking on this link: Start a conversation with those who matter most to me (Links to an external site.).  You can also click on the icon that says, "Your Conversation Starter Guide."

2. Work through the "Having the Conversation" Starter Kit which is very helpful in preparing for the conversation.  You do not turn the conversation kit in. (Another conversation starter you can use:  "Will you help me with my homework?  I have to have this difficult conversation with someone for my Issues in Grieving and Loss class ...")

3. Please reflect on your experience of having the end-of-life conversation (HTC) with your loved one.  Your reflection should be 1-3 pages, double-spaced.  Please use Times New Roman 12 pt. font and the one-inch default margins.

assignments.name: LECTURE: Grieving Children & Discussion Posts
assignments.description:
Dear Students,

"Grief in Children and Adolescents" is a very important video lecture, and because of this, it was longer than usual.  I had it edited and have inserted both the edited and longer versions here.  The edited version is 65 minutes; the unedited is 85.  If you learn best through stories, I would suggest listening to the 85-minute one at 1.25x speed. You are expected to listen to lectures. That is how you "attend" class.

This lecture starts with a clip my friend, Yvonne Fulbright, shared.  They are at her husband's grave and little Victoria is trying to comfort her mother.

Here's what I am asking you to do:

  • Watch the video lecture above and pay attention to the 3 questions that are asked.  Please post your answer to Question #3 on the discussion board, respond to 2 classmates, and be ready for a quiz on the whole lecture.

Here's why I am asking you to do it:

The lecture, video, and reading this week are on children's grief and how best to support them.  You can use the information to help grieving children understand their grief and inform parents and peers of grieving children about the best ways to support bereaved children. Not many people know how to do this well.  And if it's done poorly, it can affect children for the rest of their lives.

All 3 of your posts (your initial post and your 2 response posts) should be posted by Sunday, 11:59 pm ET (initial post = 10 pts., and response posts = 2.5 pts. each).

(Hint: Get these posts done and out of the way early in the week.  It will work better if you don't wait until Sunday!)

  7. Then click Post Reply to post it right there. Voila! How easy is that?! 😊

Question 3: USE THIS QUESTION: Using the knowledge you gathered from Prof. Patterson's lecture (the research as well as the stories), please articulate the following principles or facts that would be helpful to a) a healthcare professional, b) a grieving child, and c) the parent of a dying child:

a) What is 1 need of a dying child that would be helpful for a healthcare professional to know?

assignments.name: Mrs. Beryl Battle: Interview & Response
assignments.description:
Please write a brief summary and response to the interview with Mrs. Beryl Battle.

1. Briefly summarize the story and the main points of this interview.

2. a) What did you find most helpful professionally and why?

    b) What did you find most helpful personally and why? 

 The reflection should be double-spaced, 1 page, and in Times New Roman 12 pt. font.

assignments.name: Death and Dying Arrangements
assignments.description:
DEATH AND DYING ARRANGEMENTS

Dear Students,

Communication is one of the most essential elements of a "good" death--one that causes the least trauma to the person dying and their family.  "Open awareness" is the goal. This is communication that allows for people to talk freely about the terminal nature of the illness and the difficult circumstances and choices it brings. 

We saw a very striking example of this in the interview with Mrs. Beryl Battle. Can you imagine how much more difficult it would have been to remove Alysia from life support if she had not known she was following through on Alysia's wishes?

Here's what I'm asking you to do:

Think creatively about what you would want for your funeral service and body disposition. If there is something that is important to you, make that clear.  It is helpful to families to know what their loved ones would want. If it is an area in which you have a suggestion but would like to leave the final decision with your family, make that clear as well. Give as much instruction as is important to you, but also keep in mind that they will be the ones who are grieving. 

I encourage you to keep this assignment and combine it with your Advance Directive.  Go over it with a trusted family member and make sure your family knows where you have put it so they can follow your wishes. Update your plans as your life changes.

Here's why I'm asking you to do it:

Not only will this allow you to have the kind of ceremony that is important to you, but this is also a gift to your family as it lets them know ahead of time what you would want.  Once you are done and have communicated this to your family, you don't have to think about it again!  You can just know you are prepared. If you are having trouble with this assignment, please talk it through with your sectional instructor. 

Having done this assignment will help you balance the rational with the emotional as you support patients at end-of-life.

Here's how to do it:

READ THE LECTURE on body disposition. Here is the link below: 

6 Disposition of the Body.pdf

ANSWER THREE OF THE FOLLOWING NUMBERED QUESTIONS + THE REFLECTION. Fully discuss the following topics, making sure to include the reasons behind your choices. (Search the web for ideas about services, caskets, urns, etc.)

  1. Body Disposition: Do you want cremation, burial, or donation to medical research? Why?
  2. Type of Service: What type of funeral do you want? For example, open casket, closed casket, a memorial service (this is where the body is not present), nothing? Explain your choice.
  3. Description of Service: Describe your service and explain your choices:

a) What music would you like and why?

b) What sermon, poems, scriptures?  Explain why.

c) Do you want displays or videos? Why?

d) Who would participate in these elements?  As you write, be sure to describe why you would want these elements and people.

4. Place of Service: Where would you want the service to take place (funeral home, church, elsewhere)? Explain your choice.

5. Body Disposition Choices and Picture:

a) If being buried, what type of casket do you want? What features are important? Include a picture of it in your assignment. Explain your choices.

b) If being cremated, what type of urn would you like? Indicate the type/design and include a picture of it in your assignment. Explain your choice.

6. Last Words: What last words would you leave and to whom?

7. Graveside Service: Would you want a graveside service? If so, what would you want?

8. Resting Place:

a) If you chose burial, what cemetery would you prefer? What type of vault? Above ground or below? What type of marker? Why?

b) If you chose cremation, what will happen to your cremains? Would you like them scattered? If so, where? Or, if not scattered, where would they reside? If kept by a person, who would keep them? (If donating your body to medical research, you will receive cremains when they are done and you need to indicate what you will do with them.)

9. Reflection:

a) What is your reaction to completing this assignment?

b) What did you learn?

Remember to explain your choices for full points.

FORMAT

a) Make sure your paper is written in paragraph style--not bulleted or numbered.

b) Use an APA-style title page.

c) Double-space and use 1-inch margins, Times New Roman, 12 pt. font.

assignments.name: Advance Directive
assignments.description:
PLEASE WATCH FIRST: 1) THE INTERVIEW WITH MRS. BERYL BATTLE, AND 2) THE INTERVIEW WITH 5 WISHES.

An Advance Directive (which includes a living will and healthcare surrogate form) allows you to give directions - in advance - about how you would want to be treated if you were not able to make medical decisions or make your wishes known yourself. As a healthcare professional, you will find that an Advance Directive will help you and your patients think through things that you might never have thought of before.  It is very helpful to be aware of these resources and be able to recommend them to a patient--as well as to look for a living will in the records and be able to respond in accordance to their wishes. If you have filled one out yourself, you will be much more able to come alongside a patient, with compassion and not just head knowledge.

For this assignment, you are going to read through the 5 Wishes, and you are going to complete the AdventHealth Advance Directive forms (no signatures required for this class, just initials when asked for). After this, you will compare the 5 Wishes with the AdventHealth Advance Directive forms. As you have heard from the interview with 5 Wishes, the 5 Wishes seeks to address the personal, emotional, and spiritual needs as well as the medical wishes of the patient. (In previous trimesters, we asked students to fill out 5 Wishes; now, we are asking students to fill out the AdventHealth Advance Directive.)

For this assignment, please follow the following 3 steps:

1) READ through this 5 Wishes document: Five_Wishes.pdf

2) Complete the AdventHealth Living Will and Healthcare Surrogate forms (no signatures needed for this class, just initials when asked for), and upload the completed forms to this dropbox. The link is below. You will need to print the forms out, fill them out, and upload them (or, if you have Adobe Acrobat, you can download them and fill the PDFs using Adobe, and then upload them to the dropbox).

Here is the link to the Advance Directive document (which includes both the Living Will and Healthcare Surrogate forms): https://www.adventhealth.com/legal/advance-directives

Please read the instructions on this link that opens up, and then at the bottom of the page, choose the language in which you'd like to complete your Advance Directive forms. Click on the link and make sure you fill out and upload pages 2 and 3 of this document.

3) In the text box, answer these 2 questions:

Do you prefer the 5 Wishes advance directive OR the AdventHealth Advance Directive (Living Will and Healthcare Surrogate forms)? Why? 

 

MORE INFO:

1. For this class assignment, you are NOT required to write your signature on the AdventHealth Advance Directive forms. Without the signatures the forms ask for, these forms are not legally binding. However, if you would like the forms to be legally binding, please add the completed signatures (before or after you turn in the assignment) to your forms and distribute to the appropriate individual/s (they are listed on the forms).

2. Please do initial in the blanks where you are asked to. If you do not feel comfortable initialing, simply use checkmarks instead.

3. Please feel free to make changes to these documents as you'd like, to make sure that they reflect your wishes and you are not agreeing to something you don't want to. Even if you don't sign the forms and they are not legally binding, it is a good practice to realize that your wishes matter and to articulate them clearly.

4. If you would like your own free, downloadable PDF of the 5 Wishes in English (for your own purposes), please contact Dr. Nedelcu.

5. If you would like your own free, hard copy of 5 Wishes in Spanish, you may pick one up from Ruth Yancey, the administrative assistant for our Religion and Spiritual Care department. She is located in the General Ed building on the Orlando Campus. If you would like more than one Spanish copy, you may purchase each additional copy for $1.00 from her. To contact her and arrange to pick up a Spanish copy, please email her at ruth.yancey@ahu.edu. If you would like a Spanish copy but you are student who is not at the Orlando Campus, please let Dr. Nedelcu know.

assignments.name: LECTURE: Adult Loss & Discussion Posts
assignments.description:
Dear Students,

Here’s what I’m asking you to do.

  • Watch the video lecture above, post your answers to the question in the discussion board (question is at the end of these instructions), respond to 2 classmates, and be ready for a quiz. 
  • Always watch lectures to the end as that is how you "attend class."  Attendance is worth 5% of your grade.  To be counted as present, please watch the whole video.
  • Note: Please use the Chrome browser to access Canvas and watch Panopto videos.  (Especially with a Mac.) 

Here's why I am asking you to do it.

 Adults face different kinds of losses - and each kind of loss poses different difficulties.  This lecture looks at the types of losses most common to adults in different seasons of life - such as the death of a child, a parent, or a spouse - as well as some of the challenges that accompany that type of loss.

All 3 of your posts (your initial post and your 2 response posts) should be posted by Sunday, 11:59 pm ET (initial post = 10 pts., and each response post = 2.5 pts.).

(Hint: Get these posts done and out of the way early in the week.  It will work better if you don't wait until Sunday!)

Here's how to do it: You can decide if you want to write the response to the questions or take a video of yourself talking about your response. WHETHER YOU CHOOSE TO WRITE OR RECORD YOUR INITIAL POST TO THE LECTURE, your responses to your classmates must still be WRITTEN. 

If you choose to WRITE your initial post to a lecture:

  • Include the question you are responding to in bold type
  • Reference the lecture
  • Show thought and proofreading
  • Your answer should be at least 100 words. 
  • Include the word count in parentheses at the end.  Like this: (WC 103).

If you choose to RECORD (instead of write) your initial post to a lecture:

  • Answer the question by reading the question out loud before answering  
  • Reference the lecture 
  • Be insightful and show that you watched the video thoroughly 
  • Fully and comprehensively answer the question in no less than 2 minutes

For your two classmate responses, you must WRITE your responses:

  • Be kind and respectful
  • Use correct grammar, spelling, and punctuation in your responses. (Not "text" talk!)
  • Be at least 75 words each. (Not long, but thorough.)
  • Include the word count in parentheses at the end. Like this: (WC 78).

 

Here's how to record and upload a video:

  1. Hit Reply to post.
  2. Choose the Record/Upload Media icon that has a play button. (It is between the icons for Images and Documents).
  3. In the Upload Media window, select Record.
  4. If prompted, allow your browser to access your webcam and microphone.
  5. Make sure your webcam and microphone are on.
  6. Record your video. (Make sure it is NOT over 5 minutes.) Click on Save.
  7. Then click Post Reply to post it right there. Voila! How easy is that?! :)

QUESTION:

Please include details in your answers that show you listened to the whole lecture.   As always, I am interested in your reactions and takeaways, but the quiz questions will be specific.

Question:  Of the kinds of adult loss covered in this lecture, a) Which was most interesting to you, and b) What did you learn about it? (50+ words per section of this question)

assignments.name: A Patient's Death
assignments.description:
Students, I hope you are having a good week!  You've got this!

Here’s what I’m asking you to do:

         Skim through 3 documents below:

1) Depending on your location, look at EITHER the DNR for Florida (Do Not Resuscitate Order) OR for Colorado (Directive to Withhold CPR).

2) FAQ from a Florida Medical Examiner's Office

3) Checklist of Tasks when someone dies (from Hospice Giving Foundation)

(Nurses know the "Standard Operating Procedure" for taking care of a dead body and the DNR documents as "The Death Packet."  We are not able to provide these documents from AdventHealth for this class anymore. However, the three documents you see here will give you a more general idea of some of the issues that healthcare workers need to be acquainted with when a patient is dying or has died.) 

Please take note of things that interest you as you read these three documents and then write the one (1) most important thing you learned from each document (3 total). 

Here's why I am asking you to do it:

I want you to be prepared and know what happens after a patient has died.  These documents come from AdventHealth Orlando - but other hospitals will have similar information.   

Here's how to do it:

1. Click on the documents below.

2. Briefly describe the 1 most interesting/important things you learned from each document (3 total). 

Florida DNR

Colorado DNR

FAQ - Medical Examiner

When Someone Dies Checklist - Hospice

assignments.name: Self-Care Assessment + Self-Care Plan
assignments.description:
Dear Students,

Before you do this assignment, please make sure you have watched the lecture on "Keeping Current" and read through the "Anxiety and Self-Care Exercises" below.  Your Self-Care Plan should refer to specifics in your lecture.  PLEASE MAKE 2 SUBMISSIONS TO THIS DROPBOX: the Self-Care Assessment and the Self-Care Plan.

Here's what I want you to do:

In this module, we talk about the importance of self-care.  You will first take an assessment to see how well you are doing and then make a self-care plan to stay current in your grief and take care of yourself.  Take a look at the exercises provided as well.

Here's why I want you to do it:

Effective self-care can help you truly be present to yourself, your family, and your patients so you can continue to give compassionate care to your patients.  Many nurses and other healthcare professionals are burning out right now -- or already past the burnout point -- especially in and after the worst of COVID.  It is very important to think about how to keep but out from happening to you.  There are patients who need you.  And they need your excellent, compassionate care.

Here's how to do it:

SELF-CARE ASSESSMENT

1. Take the Self-care assessment below.

2. Upload your completed self-care assessment here.  

Self-Care Assessment 

3. Here are some exercises that you might find helpful:

Anxiety and Self-Care Exercises

SELF-CARE PLAN

1. In the first paragraph, imagine your life in the future.  Have fun with this. What do you hope to be doing? Where would you like to live?  Do you have a spouse?  A pet? etc. 

2. Address the self-care issue. What will your coping strategies be? Your paper should show that you are familiar with the strategies discussed in the lecture and that you read the anxiety and self-care exercises above this assignment in the module.

3. How are you going to stay current in your grief and not just "stuff it"? How are you going to let the emotions out? To whom are you going to share the experiences that have been very difficult for you (in a way that is HIPAA appropriate, of course)?  Make a plan. Even if you want to work out grief and stress mostly through art (for example) and you are a person of few words,

4. How are you going to tell your story ("get the words out")?  What are you going to do? With whom are you going to do it?  Will your plan include other types of support such as exercise or a church family? What other things help you release your stress in healthy ways? ( e.g. Personal Bible study and journaling? Starting or attending a small support group?)

Refer to the lecture, the interviews, and the self-care exercises for ideas and to spark ideas of your own.  Your plan should be double-spaced and in 12 pt. font.  Minimum 1 full page; Maximum 2 pages.

assignments.name: LECTURE: Keeping Current, Self-Care, & 1 Discussion Post

assignments.name: Video & Response: Helping Patients Experiencing Grief and Loss
assignments.description:
Here's what I'm asking you to do:

Watch the interview below and then write a response.

Here's why I'm asking you to do it:

In this interview, Prof. Edgerton will discuss nursing at the end of life, such as comfort measures, being present for the patient and family, caring for the needs of the family, caring for your own emotional needs, etc. What does a day in the life of a nurse caring for a dying patient look like?  Debby, who has been a nurse as well as a nurse educator, is also a breast cancer survivor and knows this material from the perspective of both the nurse and a dying patient's wife.

Here's how to do it:

2. Reflect on specifically what was helpful to you

a) Personally

b) Professionally (even if you are not going into nursing).

4. The summary should:

  • Be 1-2 pages, double-spaced
  • Have 1-inch margins (the default margins)
  • Use 12 pt. Times New Roman font.

assignments.name: Interview with 5 Wishes - Response
assignments.description:
Hello Students,

This week your Advance Directive assignment is due. One Advance Directive that I like (and that we used to use for this class) is 5 Wishes. I had the opportunity to interview Joanne Eason, the president of 5 Wishes, and I'd like you to watch that interview (it's just 17 minutes long). Dr. Nedelcu

assignments.name: Confidentiality Statement

assignments.description:
Dear Students,

This is a large class! So for grading purposes, this class is divided into sections and is assigned its own section instructor who will grade assignments, interact with you, and get to know you.  

Here’s what I’m asking you to do:

Before Week 2 begins, you will be able to see who your section instructor is by going to "People" (it's on the left bar when you are in your Canvas class). Find your name, and on the row beside your name, you will see the name of your section instructor. Your section instructor's name will not show up on the Canvas app; you'll have to access it through your computer.

Once you know who your section instructor is, come back here and watch their video (here below). If you are in Marla Nedelcu's section, you do not need to complete this assignment as long as you have already watched her video and responded to it (that was an assignment in the Week 1 Module).

Once you have watched your section instructor's video,

2) Your section instructor will respond to your comments, so make sure you go back and check your comments box.

Here’s why I’m asking you to do it:

This is a great way to get to know and feel more comfortable with your section instructor. We look forward to getting to know you this trimester, and this assignment is one of the first ways you can get to know us and connect with us.

assignments.name: Does this Class Matter? A Classmate's Story of Uncommon Compassion
assignments.description:
Dear Students,

Last trimester, after the mandatory Course Expectations Zoom, a student stayed on to talk with me. She shared her story. It was so moving, it brought tears to my eyes. I knew the rest of my students needed to hear her story too, and she gave me permission to record her story.

This is Dinelly Penzo's story about the difference that uncommon compassion makes in the midst of tragedy. May it inspire you to be the kind of healthcare professional that she speaks of. 

WHAT TO DO:

1. Watch the video below.

2. To the dropbox, submit your answers to the following questions. Copy these questions to your document (and put them in bold font), and then write your answers under them.

     a) Which healthcare professional that Dinelly mentioned most impressed you? Why?

     b) Reflect on the kind of healthcare professional you want to be. Based on this reflection (and on your reflection on this story), name two things that you want to do to make your patients feel uncommon compassion.

Blessings to you. I am excited about the difference that each of you can make as you touch thousands of lives with uncommon compassion.

assignments.name: Introduction to Prof. Patterson and Class - Video and Quiz
assignments.description:
DIRECTIONS:

  1. Please watch the video below and take the quiz based on it.  It introduces the course and Prof. Alicia Patterson. Prof. Patterson was the developer of this course, but has left full-time teaching to launch Confluence Grief and Loss Coaching. Currently, Dr. Marla Nedelcu is the lead instructor for this course. She is committed to your growth and success in this class and life, so please don't hesitate to reach out if you want to talk or need any help!   
  2. When you are done watching the video, please take the quiz. We are looking for answers that show careful listening and depth of understanding. Go back and find the video section if you are unsure of an answer.

About the quiz: The quiz will close 20 minutes after you begin. You are responsible to make sure that your internet connection is solid and that your device does not die. You only will be able to retake a quiz if we have a documented instance of power or internet loss or AHU website failure.

NOTE: When you get your quiz score, don't be concerned if you get a low score initially. It probably means it hasn't been graded by a human yet!😊

Your short answer questions will not be given credit until then. Canvas can only grade objective questions like T/F and multiple choice.  

Note: If you have a Mac, please use the Chrome browser to access Canvas and view the Panopto videos.

If you still have trouble watching the video here, go to "Panopto Recordings" in the menu to the left. Press CTRL-f on your keyboard to search by the name of the video.

assignments.name: EXTRA CREDIT: Canvas Course Evaluation: DUE Friday by 8:00 PM EDT
assignments.description:
Dear Students,

Here's what I'm asking you to do:

Take the Canvas Course Evaluation when it becomes available.

Here's why I am asking you to do it:

This helps improve courses and also lets the administration know which professors are doing a good job.  Those who do it will get a 1% boost to their grade.  So if you had an 89.4% in the class, for example, it would bump your grade to a 90.4.

Here's how to do it:

  1. Take the Canvas Course Evaluation when it pops up in the menu to the left.
  2. After you have taken the evaluation, which is anonymous, take a picture of the proof of having done it.
  3. Upload the photo here.  

The administration takes these evaluations seriously, so please be both honest and gracious! 

Thank you.  The sectional instructors and I were privileged to listen to and respond to your stories and assignments this trimester.  We pray that what you learned in this class will serve you well and that you will refer back to it many times over your career.

Blessings,

Dr. Nedelcu

assignments.name: Reflection on Extra-Credit Experience
assignments.description:
DIRECTIONS:

*Please try to complete this assignment one week or less after your extra-credit experience.*

If you choose to complete one of these extra-credit activities (Hospice Experience or Zoom Grief Support Group), please write a short reflection of your experience in order to earn your extra credit. 

  1. What was the experience like for you?
  2. What is the most important thing you learned? 

Your response only needs to be a 1/2 page long, double-spaced.  Just articulate what you learned.

assignments.name: Extra Credit: Interview with Nurse "See See" Rigney
assignments.description:
Dear Students,

Nurse "See See" is a delightful 94-year-old nurse in this interview. You will enjoy meeting her! This assignment is for 10 extra credit points, which means that it's optional. To complete it, read the directions and then see the video below, where Prof. Patterson interviews Nurse See See. 

Here’s what I’m asking you to do:

Carefully watch and listen to this interview with Florence "See See" Rigney and respond to the 4 questions below.

Here’s why I’m asking you to do it:

You know you will deal with death and dying in your job. A good question to keep in mind as you go through this class is "Will I have resilience?"  As you go through this course, I hope you will collect information that will help you answer that.

As Jay Perez said, we live our lives in stories - and we understand our lives in stories.  So sometimes we learn best just by listening to stories! The stories of ordinary people who have gone before us—as in the case of See See Rigney. These stories can give us wisdom, inspire, and instruct us. 

See See is a great example of resilience.  I hope you will enjoy this interview with a woman whose story has gone viral around the world. My hope for you is that you will love your job for decades - like See See.  (If you want to watch a short NBC news clip on this feisty 94-year-old nurse, here's a link:  https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/oldest-working-nurse-country-retires-age-96-n1274521) 

Here’s how to do it (questions based on Prof. Patterson's interview with See See below):

  1. a) How did Nurse Rigney react when she made a major medical mistake while in nursing school?  b) What helped her continue?
  2. Name three (3) changes she saw over the course of her nursing career.
  3. Name two (2) characteristics that helped See See have resilience and kept her passionate about her career over seven decades.
  4. What have you learned from listening to the life of Nurse Rigney that has inspired and instructed you?

assignments.name: Research Activity 1
assignments.description:
Instructions:

Collect academic 3 articles that have sociological contents and contexts;

  • one article should have a local emphasis (based on the state in which you're located);
  • another must be national focus (anywhere in the U.S.),
  • and one article should have an international/global emphasis.

Some examples of focus for sociological implications  include, but are not limited to socialization, health, education, families, culture, economic development, religion, stratification, globalization, politics, groups, traditions, symbolic interactionism, conflict, or functionalism

1. Read your articles.
2. Write a brief summary, sociological implications and reflection for each article. Use the following format as you analyze each article:

I. Brief summary of article

II. Sociological Implications: (A short paragraph of supporting data for each implication, this must be aligned to what you read in the article).

(i) article 1/implication 1

(ii) article 2/ implication 2

(iii) article 3/ implication 3

III. Reflection: (A paragraph or two).

Your submission MUST include:

  • the source of the information (reference-APA),
  • how the article relates to each sociological concepts, bold the sociological implications you identify and make sure there is supporting data from the article being analyzed.
  • overall reflection to the articles (include your moral/ethical and critical thinking, changes you may make, do you care about the issue, etc.)

3. Cite each article in APA format on a reference page

 

 

 

Example:

RA1 Example.docx

assignments.name: Research Activity 2
assignments.description:
Instructions:

Collect 3 articles that have sociological contents and contexts;

  • one article should have a local focus,
  • one article should have a national focus,
  • and one article should have an international/global emphasis.

Some examples of focus for sociological implications include, but are not limited to socialization, health, education, families, culture, economic development, religion, stratification, globalization, politics, groups, traditions, symbolic interactionism, conflict, or functionalism.


You are to choose ONE OVERALL TOPIC.

Find THREE research articles that pertain to that ONE topic.

You are to write up a BRIEF research outline regarding your topic from a socioligical perspective.

The outline should look as such:
-Cover page-

1. Introduction of your topic
*If you are stating ANY facts about your topic, they NEED to be cited!

2. The body of your paper
*1 paragraph should analyze and cite from your local research article
*1 paragraph should analyze and cite from your national research article
*1 paragraph should analyze and cite from your global research article

**Again, any fact needs to be cited. This is not an opinion based paper.

3. Conclusion
*please wrap up your topic, cite any bold facts *if you include them* and again, state your sociological implication(s).

4. References

You can have more than one sociological implication for one topic. Your submission MUST include:

  • the source of the information (reference-APA),
  • how the article relates to your sociological concepts, bold the sociological implication(s) you identify and make sure there is supporting data from the article being analyzed.

 Cite each article in APA format on a reference page

 

Example:

RA1 Example-1.docx
